title: SU(N) eigenstates with Physics-Informed Neural Networks
text:
Information about my talk
I gave a talk at ECT* in Trento about my recent arxiv submission 2510.26904. I discussed how one can perform an adiabatic learning of a Physics-Informed Neural Network in order to find the renormalization flow of the eigenfunctions and energies of a SU(N) lattice gauge theory.

Current employer: University of Bern
Job title: Postdoctoral Researcher
Education: PhD in Theoretical Physics

My main areas of interest are:

Quantum Field Theories on the lattice, QCD phenomenology
Machine Learning for scientific applications, Physics-Informed Neural Networks
Markov chain Monte Carlo, Bayesian algorithms

Education | Experience | Publications | Teaching | Software

title: Lattice Data Tools
text:
I am the creator and maintainer of the library lattice_data_tools, a software toolkit for the statistical analysis of lattice data. Some features are, for instance:

Extraction of effective masses and amplitudes from lattice correlators
Standard routines in the calculation of the hadronic contributions to \((g-2)_\mu\)
Analysis of Monte Carlo trajectories
Bootstrap and jackknife sampling
Least-squares fit of functions \(\mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^{m}\)
Bayesian Model Averaging, Akaikeâ€™s Information Criterion

lattice_data_tools is also part of the Lattice QFT software list.

title: Hadron 2021 conference
text:
Information
From the 26th July 2021 to the 30th July 2022 I attended the Hadron 2021 international conference. The conference took place in the same days of the Lattice 2021 conference
The conference took place remotely due to the global emergency causeb by the COVID pandemic.
In my talk I talked about the lattice calculation of the mass splittings of the nucleons (i.e.Â the the mass difference between neutron and proton) and the ones of the \(\Delta(1232)\) resonances. I showed how it is possible to find this mass splitting by using a purely hadronic renormalization scheme and perturbation theory at 1st order in \(\alpha_\text{em}\) and \(\frac{(m_d-m_u)}{\Lambda_\text{QCD}}\) with the RM123 method. Furthermore, I showed how one can use leading order expensions to relate the \(\Delta\)s mass splittings among each other.

title: Lattice 2022 conference
text:
Information
From the 8th Aug.Â 2022 to the 13th of August 2022 I attended the Lattice 2022 international conference in Bonn, Germany. As one of the locals (check my experience section) I contributed to the organization, providing support also for the technical tasks related to video and audio broadcasting during the presentations.
In my talk I talked about the Hamiltonian limit in lattice gauge theories, and how to obtain it in the Lagrangian formalism by sending the temporal lattice spacing to zero. This is relevant for match the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formalisms at finite lattice spacing, where they differ for discretization effects.

title: Lattice 2021 conference
text:
Information
From the 26th July 2021 to the 30th July 2022 I attended the Lattice 2021 international conference, at MIT. The conference took place remotely due to the global emergency causeb by the COVID pandemic.
In my talk I talked about the part of my PhD thesis project consisting in the determination of the mass difference between neutron and proton with lattice calculations. I showed how it is possible to find this mass splitting by using a purely hadronic renormalization scheme and perturbation theory at 1st order in \(\alpha_\text{em}\) and \(\frac{(m_d-m_u)}{\Lambda_\text{QCD}}\) with the RM123 method.

title: Eyes on Mars
text:
Information
On the 15th Feb.Â 2019 I helped in the organization of the event Eyes on Mars (Occhi su Marte ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹), at the department of Mathematics and Physics of the Roma Tre University.
The event consisted in a series of seminars, presentation, hands-on activities for kids and observations with the telescope. The even had a broad scope for the general audience, covering several talks and activities about science in general.
I contributed to the organization of the whole event and presented myself a demonstration of the Barkhausen effect, which provides a macroscopic evidence of the formation of Weiss domains in ferromagnetic materials.
In my presentation with title Electromagneticâ€¦ Attractions (Attrazioniâ€¦ elettromagnetiche ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹), I used a transformer connected to a loudspeaker and a magnet. Passing the magnet next to the metal surrounding the transformer me and Alessio Rettaroli were able to reproduce in the loudspeaker the typical clicking noise of Weiss domains flip.

title: \(\mathrm{SU(N)}\) lattice gauge theories with Physics-Informed Neural Networks
text:
Preamble
In Quantum Mechanics the fundamental equations are the SchrÃ¶dinger equations. One depends on time, determining the evolution of a physical state: \[i \partial_t \ket{\psi} = H \ket{\psi}\]
The other is the eigenvalue equation for the \(n\)-th eigenstate \(\psi_n\): \[H \ket{\psi}_n = E \ket{\psi}_n\]
If the are able to solve the latter, the time evolution reads: \[
\ket{\psi(0)} = \sum_n c_n \ket{\psi}_n
\, \to \,
\ket{\psi(t)} = \sum_n c_n e^{-i E_n t} \ket{\psi}_n
\]
Note: Solving the SchrÃ¶dinger equations can be simpler for some values of the parameters in the Hamiltonian (e.g.Â eq can use perturbation theory). For others, we have to resort to numerical methods.


Summary of the paper
In this paper I proposed an algorithm to solve the eigenvalue equation with a neural network. The usefulness is the ability to solve the eigenvalue equation with a form of unsupervised learning, for values the coupling where the analytic solution is not known.
The key elements of originality are:

This has never been done for lattice gauge theories, and has the potential of overcoming the exponential curse of the Hilbert space size scaling.
I define and successfully test a procedure to compute the coupling dependence of the solution (i.e.Â the renormalization flow of the eigenfunctions and energies)
The method is general and can be applied also to learn the dependence on other parameters of the Hamiltonian
This is an Hamiltonian method. As such, it does not suffer from the typical Monte Carlo hindrances: critical slowing down, topological freezing, sign problem, etc.
